prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a standard continuum observations in Band 7 at 345 GHz.

The principle aim of the proposal is to image the distorting effects of low mass substructures that have masses of the order 10^7 M solar. Based on lens models, such masses should produce distortions on the scale of 30-40 mas. Therefore, to detect these distortions and potentially directly see mini-Einstein rings on the extended arcs, will require a resolution of 40 mas. From our work on SDP.81, we found that the dust has a LAS of about 0.5 arcsec, but achieving 0.2 arcsec for the LAS will be sufficient to also study the properties of the background source.

Our sensitivity calculations are based on the expected surface brightness given the total flux of the source and what we experienced in the case of the long baseline observations of SDP.81 (typically 2-4 times fainter than our targets). Note that the exact sensitivity is dependent on the observed structure of the source, which will be determined with these observations. Note that our lensing code fits to the visibilities of the source and so we derive a model that must account for the observed total flux density of the source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The existence of abundant cold dark matter substructure is an unavoidable consequence of the Cold Dark Matter paradigm. Despite its clear theoretical prediction, a glaring discrepancy with the number of luminous satellites around the Milky Way (MW) has been brought to light, i.e. the missing satellite problem. Despite great progress to quantify this problem, the MW could be a biased environment, not representative of the typical universe, and the problem remains unsolved as of yet. Surface brightness anomalies of gravitationally lensed images provide a complementary and unique channel to detect substructure beyond the local Universe in massive, mostly early-type, galaxies. Here we propose to observe a sample of 10 gravitational lens systems to detect dark substructures with masses of the order of 10^7 M_sun. In combination with already in-hand VLBI (sensitivity 10^6 M_sun), HST and Keck AO (sensitivity 10^8 M_sun) observations, this will allow us to map the full substructure mass function and set stringent observational constraints on the properties of dark matter.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge, University of
Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
